results.title: New Guinea Patrol
results.creator_credit: Maslyn Williams, Peter Dimond, Australian Commonwealth Film Unit and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: Follows the work of a three-month expedition to survey and open up uncontrolled territory in the Papuan highlands.

results.title: Native Earth
results.creator_credit: John Heyer and Australian National Film Board
results.brief_description: A study of Australia’s responsibilities and administration issues in Papua New Guinea immediately after World War 2, with particular emphasis on the life and the needs of Papuans. Commentary by Peter Finch, researched by Catherine Duncan, script by Catherine Duncan, photography by Frank Bagnall, music by John Kay.

results.title: The Mount Hagen Show
results.creator_credit: Boris Cook and Information and Extension Services for the people of Papua New Guinea
results.brief_description: A mass gathering of highland tribes of diverse customs was indicative of the beginnings of unity and prosperity in Papua and New Guinea. This was the hope expressed by Lord de L’Isle when he declared the Mount Hagen Show open. But it is only the beginning. The response of brightly painted feather bedecked natives to the throb of drums; the incongruousness of their participation in bicycle racing and dodgem cars; the mixed expressions of curiosity and distrust amongst the native spectators, clearly show that the path to change is a long one.

results.title: Mexico 75: no place else in the world to be
results.creator_credit: Patricia Edgar and Centre for the Study of Educational Communication and Media, LaTrobe University
results.brief_description: A record of the International Women’s Conference in Mexico City in 1975. The film sets the Conference in the context of an underdeveloped country and discusses the relevance of the women’s movement to third world countries. There is special emphasis on the contribution of the Australian delegation.

results.title: Jim Serafim goes to School
results.creator_credit: David Roberts, Jan Sharp and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Our multicultural society”.
A Greek child’s first day at school. Demonstrates the difficulties non-English speaking children and their parents have in their “new” country.

results.title: How to keep a job
results.brief_description: Discusses the habits and attitudes that make for job success once the job is obtained. A man seeking a new job after being fired at his last job is interviewed by the Personnel director of a company and is told that employers want men who are dependable, willing to work, co-operate, loyal and possess initiative.

results.title: A Half million teenagers
results.brief_description: Studies the physiology aspects of venereal disease. Uses animation to show how the organisms of gonorrhea and syphilis enter and affect the body and how the diseases may be recognised. Stresses the need for treatment, pointing out that there is a cure for both diseases.

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.

results.title: Forgotten people
results.creator_credit: Barry Merton and Mathias, Kenyon and Merton Pictures
results.brief_description:
Shows the work of the Aborigines Advancement League particularly of Pastor Doug Nicholls and Bill Onus. They visit the settlements of Rumbaland, Robinvale and Dareton, showing the primitive conditions in which the aborigines are forced to live. Government housing is not provided at a sufficient rate. This film stresses the need for more positive action.
Sponsored by the Aborigines Advancement League (Victoria) in the wake of the 1967 Referendum, and featuring two of the League’s founding members in Nicholls and Onus.

results.title: The Car Stealers
results.creator_credit: Eric L. Morris, Geoffrey Thompson, Council of Fire and Accident Underwriters and Cine Services
results.brief_description: Dramatizes the problem of car theft and joy-riding by young teenagers in Australia. Points out to car owners and parents how their carelessness can be partly responsible. Shows safety devices and security checks for car-owners. Made with the co-operation of the Victorian Police.
